elements.content: Antibacterial agents with two-photon absorption are expected to play a significant role in biomedical science. Herein, two novel organotin complexes, HLSn1 and HLSn2, based on coumarin were designed, synthesized, and systematically investigated. It was found that these complexes possessed suitable two-photon-active cross sections in the near-infrared region. Moreover, complex HLSn1 could efficiently inhibit the growth of Gram-negative Escherichia coli and Gram-positive Bacillus subtilis, especially the latter with a minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC; 90%) of 2 ± 0.14 μg mL–1, which is lower than that of Kanamycin (Kana, 8 ± 0.42 μg mL–1). Importantly, two-photon imaging and superresolution development of bacterial stain revealed that complex HLSn1 can react with bacterial membranes, producing reactive oxygen species (ROS) and leading to cell death. These outcomes provide promising applications in the superresolution bacteria imaging, diagnostics, and treatment of bacterial infectious.

elements.content: Two-photon-active organotin­(IV) complex HLSn1 was confirmed to have strong antibacterial activity against Gram-positive Bacillus subtilis with a minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC; 90%) of 2 ± 0.14 μg mL−1. The bacterial membrane was punctured by complex HLSn1 because of the generation of ROS, from which the cytoplasmic components (nucleic acid, etc.) were subsequently discharged. To the best of our knowledge, it was the first time that an organotin­(IV) complex was used for two-photon and superresolution bacteria imaging to gain insight into the antibacterial process.

elements.content: Microbial contamination and infections have presented an unparalleled challenge to antimicrobial research in the past few decades. Because they arise from pathogens and can spread globally, they are responsible for more than 10 million deaths every year in the world and have become a worldwide threat to human health. Even worse, resistance of the microorganisms toward the available antibiotics is treating the effective prophylaxis and cure of increasing infections. To this end, alternative antibacterial agents able to overcome the resistance issues are urgently needed.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Microbial contamination and infections have presented an unparalleled challenge to antimicrobial research in the past few decades. Because they arise from pathogens and can spread globally, they are responsible for more than 10 million deaths every year in the world and have become a worldwide threat to human health. Even worse, resistance of the microorganisms toward the available antibiotics is treating the effective prophylaxis and cure of increasing infections. To this end, alternative antibacterial agents able to overcome the resistance issues are urgently needed.

elements.content: Organotin­(IV) compounds are of large dosages in industry and are considerable in new antibiotic development because of their extensive applications, including important biological activities. These compounds are capable of damaging the bacterial cell wall by altering its wall ingredients, blocking the protein synthesis, and possibly disturbing the replication of DNA or RNA. Understanding these antibacterial mechanisms powerfully favors the exploration of new antibacterial agents.

elements.content: In addition to the emergency need for new antibiotics to fight the increasing resistance, early diagnosis of bacterial infections is of crucial importance. Fluorescent probes capable of offering rapid and direct analysis of various biological events with high sensitivity have acted as useful tools to monitor bacterial infections and investigate the mechanisms of antibacterial assay. However, largely reported probes are restricted to one-photon fluorescence microscopy (OPFM) excited at shorter wavelength, which suffers nonspecific background signals, inefficient collection for tissue images, and possible photodamage. Two-photon fluorescence microscopy, a novel development appliance for life science research, exhibits promising superiority over OPFM technology, including minimized autofluorescence background, less photodamage, and higher penetration depth. Therefore, it will be highly desirable that exploitation of specific theranostic agents could not only retard the growth of bacteria but also serve as a noninvasive imaging tool for bacterial strains to promote antimicrobial investigation.

elements.content: In our previous work, several series of two-photon-active organotin complexes were designed and synthesized, some of which were reported for the visualization of anticancer action. However, to the best our knowledge, no organotin complex used for two-photon imaging and superresolution development of bacterial strains has been reported to understand the mechanism of antimicrobial assay.

elements.content: With this in mind, two novel organotin complexes (HLSn1 and HLSn2) based on our previous work were designed for several considerations. The cyano group with strong electron-withdrawing ability was introduced in the novel designed ligand HL to make it easier to coordinate with tin­(IV), forming higher stable organotin complexes. On the other hand, the cyano group can also tune the push–pull electronic structure within whole molecule and regulate the photophysical properties. The comprehensive studies indicated that the spectra of complexes HLSn1 and HLSn2 performed obvious bathochromic shifts compared with LSn1 and LSn2(Figure S1). Interestingly, complex HLSn1 possessed higher antimicrobial activity against Gram-positive Bacillus subtilis than Kana, and it has been effectively used for two-photon imaging and superresolution development in antibacterial assay.

Experimental Section

Synthesis of HL 

To an acetonitrile solution (50 mL) of 7-(diethylamino)-2-oxo-2H-chromene-3-carbaldehyde (5 mmol, 1.20 g) was added cyanoacetic acid (10 mmol, 0.85 g) and then 3 drops of piperidine. The reaction mixture were stirred for 5 h at 80 °C. When cooled to room temperature, the solvent was removed to afford a coarse product and recrystallized in acetonitrile to obtain atrovirens solids. Yield: 85%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 400 MHz): δ 1.16 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 6H), 3.54 (q, J = 7.1 Hz, 4H), 6.65 (d, J = 1.9 Hz, 1H), 6.85 (dd, J 1= 9.2 Hz, J 2 = 6.4 Hz, 1H), 7.62 (d, J = 9.1 Hz, 1H), 8.25 (s, 1H), 8.76 (s, 1H), 13.67 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6, 100 MHz): δ 12.87, 45.12, 97.08, 99.60, 108.48, 109.99, 111.23, 117.11, 132.76, 144.33, 147.46, 153.88, 157.98, 160.67, 164.11. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3427, 2976, 2930, 2503, 2219, 1726, 1679, 1616, 1537, 1502, 1419, 1345, 1269, 1199, 1132, 1047, 1008, 963, 850, 812, 745, 638, 573, 528, 458. MS (MALDI-TOF, H). Calcd: m/z 312.11. Found: m/z 311.54. Anal. Calcd for C17H16N2O: C, 65.39; H, 5.17; N, 8.96. Found: C, 65.43; H, 5.14; N, 8.98.

A clear solution was generated and refluxed for 12 h. Then, the solvent was removed to obtain compound HLSn1 (red solid; ). Yield: 92%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 400 MHz): δ 0.87 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 10H), 1.15 (m, 12H), 1.32 (m, 6H), 1.63 (m, 5H), 3.51 (q, J = 7.1 Hz, 4H), 6.61 (s, 1H), 6.80 (dd, J 1 = 6.8 Hz, J 2 = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.56 (d, J = 9.1 Hz, 1H), 8.11 (s, 1H), 8.66 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6, 100 MHz): δ 11.95, 14.01, 19.03, 26.37, 26.98, 43.85, 95.95, 107.71, 110.22, 117.68, 131.55, 142.72, 144.02, 152.60, 156.99, 160.31, 164.40. Complex HLSn1 crystallized in the monoclinic system with space group P21/c, and for complex HLSn2, it was an orthorhombic system with space group Pbca (Table S1). As displayed in , there are four coordinated bonds around a central Sn atom in complexes HLSn1 and HLSn2, namely, three Sn–C bonds and one Sn–O bond. Meanwhile, in complex HLSn1, the asymmetric unit is composed of two molecules (Figure S2), which is linked by Sn1–O6. The bond lengths of Sn1–O6 (2.635 Å; the O atom from the carboxylic acid) and Sn2–O9 (2.436 Å; the O atom from the solvent molecule H2O) are longer than that of the normal Sn1–O1 (2.141 Å) bond length, manifesting that the O6 and O9 atoms did not participate in the coordination, so the other HLSn1 molecule and solvent molecule H2O were omitted for clarity, which was certified by elemental analysis, 1H and 119Sn NMR, mass spectrometry (MS) spectra, and thermogravimetric (TG) analysis. No hydrogen signal of the H2O molecule could be detected in the 1H NMR spectrum of HLSn1(Figure S6), a single chemical shift of Sn was observed in the 119Sn NMR spectrum (Figure S7), and the relative molecular mass of [HLSn1 + H2O] or [2HLSn1 + H2O] could not be found in the MS spectrum (Figure S9). In addition, TG curves shown in Figure S14 exhibited that the beginning of weight loss for HLSn1 is over 200 °C. Taken together, the solvent molecule H2O and O6 (the O atom from the carboxylic acid) did not participate in the coordination in complex HLSn1.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures

Complex HLSn1 crystallized in the monoclinic system with space group P21/c, and for complex HLSn2, it was an orthorhombic system with space group Pbca (Table S1). As displayed in , there are four coordinated bonds around a central Sn atom in complexes HLSn1 and HLSn2, namely, three Sn-C bonds and one Sn-O bond. Meanwhile, in complex HLSn1, the asymmetric unit is composed of two molecules (Figure S2), which is linked by Sn1-O6. The bond lengths of Sn1-O6 (2.635 Å; the O atom from the carboxylic acid) and Sn2-O9 (2.436 Å; the O atom from the solvent molecule H2O) are longer than that of the normal Sn1-O1 (2.141 Å) bond length, manifesting that the O6 and O9 atoms did not participate in the coordination, so the other HLSn1 molecule and solvent molecule H2O were omitted for clarity, which was certified by elemental analysis, 1H and 119Sn NMR, mass spectrometry (MS) spectra, and thermogravimetric (TG) analysis. No hydrogen signal of the H2O molecule could be detected in the 1H NMR spectrum of HLSn1(Figure S6), a single chemical shift of Sn was observed in the 119Sn NMR spectrum (Figure S7), and the relative molecular mass of [HLSn1 + H2O] or [2HLSn1 + H2O] could not be found in the MS spectrum (Figure S9). In addition, TG curves shown in Figure S14 exhibited that the beginning of weight loss for HLSn1 is over 200 °C. Taken together, the solvent molecule H2O and O6 (the O atom from the carboxylic acid) did not participate in the coordination in complex HLSn1.

elements.content: Adjacent molecules of complex HLSn1 interact with each other through bonds Sn1---O6 and Sn2---O6---O7 to form a one-dimensional (1D) chain structure (b). Complex HLSn2 forms a 1D infinite chain by the metal-bound peripheral coumarin O2 and carboxyl O4 running along the a axis (Sn1---O4 and Sn1---O2), as displayed in d.

Complex HLSn2 forms a 1D infinite chain by the metal-bound peripheral coumarin O2 and carboxyl O4 running along the a axis (Sn1---O4 and Sn1---O2), as displayed in d.

elements.content: The dihedral angles between the coumarin unit and vinyl group (2.35° for HLSn1 and 2.01° for HLSn2, respectively) are smaller than those of LSn1 and LSn2, which could be attributed to the introduction of a cyano group within the molecule. The coumarin group adjoins the C–Sn–O plane, with the dihedral angles being 10.65° for HLSn1 and 17.14° for HLSn2. These structural features manifest that HLSn1 and HLSn2 possessed a highly delocalized π-electron system, which may generate two-photon absorption properties.

The coumarin group adjoins the C-Sn-O plane, with the dihedral angles being 10.65° for HLSn1 and 17.14° for HLSn2. These structural features manifest that HLSn1 and HLSn2 possessed a highly delocalized π-electron system, which may generate two-photon absorption properties.

elements.content: As shown in a, the ligand HL and relative complexes (HLSn1 and HLSn2) displayed one major absorption band at about 450 nm, and the emission bands were located around 545 nm in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS; pH = 7.42, 0.02% Triton X-100, a simulated biological system), which presented a remarkable bathochromic shift compared with those of LSn1 and LSn2 (∼20 nm for absorption spectra and ∼30 nm for emission spectra). This phenomenon could be attributed to the effect of the cyano group. Time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) was carried out to further confirm this (b and Table S4). For these assessed compounds, the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO, H) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO, L) are mainly located at the coumarin carboxylic acid ester and cyano unit, suggesting that the electron density of the cyano unit participated in a H → L transition. Additionally, the emission intensities of complexes HLSn1 and HLSn2 were a little weaker than that of the corresponding free ligand HL, which can be attributed to the fact that the introduction of the Sn atom increased the spin–orbit coupling of the fluorescent molecule and influenced the radiative rate constant (k r) and nonradiative rate constant (k nr) (listed in Table S5), leading to a decrease of the fluorescence intensity. It was found that k r and k nr of HL are both larger than those of HLSn1 and HLSn2; herein, the fluorescence intensity may primarily depend on the radiative rate constant.
elements.clean_text:
Photophysical Properties

As shown in a, the ligand HL and relative complexes (HLSn1 and HLSn2) displayed one major absorption band at about 450 nm, and the emission bands were located around 545 nm in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS; pH = 7.42, 0.02% Triton X-100, a simulated biological system), which presented a remarkable bathochromic shift compared with those of LSn1 and LSn2 (~20 nm for absorption spectra and ~30 nm for emission spectra). This phenomenon could be attributed to the effect of the cyano group. Time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) was carried out to further confirm this (b and Table S4). For these assessed compounds, the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO, H) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO, L) are mainly located at the coumarin carboxylic acid ester and cyano unit, suggesting that the electron density of the cyano unit participated in a H → L transition. Additionally, the emission intensities of complexes HLSn1 and HLSn2 were a little weaker than that of the corresponding free ligand HL, which can be attributed to the fact that the introduction of the Sn atom increased the spin-orbit coupling of the fluorescent molecule and influenced the radiative rate constant (k r) and nonradiative rate constant (k nr) (listed in Table S5), leading to a decrease of the fluorescence intensity. It was found that k r and k nr of HL are both larger than those of HLSn1 and HLSn2; herein, the fluorescence intensity may primarily depend on the radiative rate constant.

elements.content: Plots of two-photon excited emission intensity versus change of the wavelength for HL, HLSn1, and HLSn2 are listed in Figure S15. Influenced by the organotin atom, the maximum two-photon-active cross section (Φσmax) of HL (98 GM) was larger than those of HLSn1 (69 GM) and HLSn2 (61 GM). Moreover, Φσmax of HLSn1 and HLSn2 remain above 50 GM in the NIR, and this favors the applications for biological imaging.

elements.content: The antibacterial screening of HL, HLSn1, HLSn2, and a standard antibacterial Kanamycin (Kana) against Gram-positive B. subtilis and Gram-negative Escherichia coli was reflected by an optical density (OD) at 600 nm. As shown in , complexes HLSn1 and HLSn2 manifested much higher antimicrobial activity than ligand HL against the bacteria because of the effect of the Sn atom. On the other hand, compared to HLSn2, HLSn1 showed a little stronger antibacterial activity, which could be attributed to the high lipophilicity of HLSn1 with the flexible alkyl chains and ease of absorption by the bacterial membrane, leading to damage to the bacterial membrane. Although HLSn1 exhibited weaker antibacterial activity than Kana against Gram-positive E. coli, it displayed a lower MIC value than Kana against Gram-positive B. subtilis, so it was selected to be studied in detail.
elements.clean_text:
Investigation of the Antibacterial Properties

The antibacterial screening of HL, HLSn1, HLSn2, and a standard antibacterial Kanamycin (Kana) against Gram-positive B. subtilis and Gram-negative Escherichia coli was reflected by an optical density (OD) at 600 nm. As shown in , complexes HLSn1 and HLSn2 manifested much higher antimicrobial activity than ligand HL against the bacteria because of the effect of the Sn atom. On the other hand, compared to HLSn2, HLSn1 showed a little stronger antibacterial activity, which could be attributed to the high lipophilicity of HLSn1 with the flexible alkyl chains and ease of absorption by the bacterial membrane, leading to damage to the bacterial membrane. Although HLSn1 exhibited weaker antibacterial activity than Kana against Gram-positive E. coli, it displayed a lower MIC value than Kana against Gram-positive B. subtilis, so it was selected to be studied in detail.

elements.content: Normalized OD of E. coli and B. subtilis. Suspensions were measured at 600 nm in lysogeny broth at 37 °C after the introduction of different concentrations of HL, HLSn1, HLSn2, and Kana (DMSO solution), respectively, for 24 h. Control groups were bacteria-treated without antibacterial agents. The error bars represent the standard deviation (n = 3).
elements.clean_text: 3  Normalized OD of E. coli and B. subtilis. Suspensions were measured at 600 nm in lysogeny broth at 37 °C after the introduction of different concentrations of HL, HLSn1, HLSn2, and Kana (DMSO solution), respectively, for 24 h. Control groups were bacteria-treated without antibacterial agents. The error bars represent the standard deviation (n = 3).

elements.content: Inhibition zone experiments were also implemented to evaluate the antimicrobial activity of HLSn1. Antibacterial activity data of HLSn1 and Kana are listed in , which is consistent with the antibacterial screening assessed above. The obvious inhibition zones shown in a further confirm that HLSn1 could kill bacteria efficiently. Parts b and c of displayed the values of the OD (λ = 600 nm) at different incubation times. Notably, in the absence of HLSn1, the normal growth characteristics of both E. coli and B. subtilis were detected during a culture period of 24 h. In sharp contrast, the sample treated with HLSn1 retained a very low cell concentration (∼0.05 OD) even after incubation for 24 h, indicating that the growth of two types of bacterial cells was effectively inhibited by complex HLSn1.

Hydrolytic Stability and Cell Viability

The stability under physiological conditions is essential for interpretation of the imaging and inhibitory data. The 1H NMR spectra of complex HLSn1 in aqueous conditions were investigated in a D2O and DMSO-d 6 mixture (1/5, v/v). a revealed that complex HLSn1 exhibited excellent stability after a water bath for 24 h at 37 °C.

elements.content: It is noted that biofilm-associated infection has presented another medical problem because of the low penetration of antimicrobial agents into extracellular polymeric substances. Hence, 200-μm-thick HepG2 (human hepatoma cell line) three-dimensional (3D) multicellular spheroids (MCSs) were incubated with complex HLSn1 (1 μg mL–1) to assess the penetration ability. c indicated that obvious fluorescence was observed in the MCSs to a depth of over 94 μm, implying that complex HLSn1 can break through the biofilm barrier and aggregate in MCSs. This result demonstrated that complex HLSn1 has potential application in vivo.
elements.clean_text:
Tissue Permeability

It is noted that biofilm-associated infection has presented another medical problem because of the low penetration of antimicrobial agents into extracellular polymeric substances. Hence, 200-μm-thick HepG2 (human hepatoma cell line) three-dimensional (3D) multicellular spheroids (MCSs) were incubated with complex HLSn1 (1 μg mL-1) to assess the penetration ability. c indicated that obvious fluorescence was observed in the MCSs to a depth of over 94 μm, implying that complex HLSn1 can break through the biofilm barrier and aggregate in MCSs. This result demonstrated that complex HLSn1 has potential application in vivo.

elements.content: Given the remarkable two-photon absorption property of HLSn1, it was applied to obtain insight into the antibacterial process through two-photon confocal microscopy. Herein, propidium iodide (PI) without membrane permeability was chosen to color dead bacteria for comparison. As revealed in , intense fluorescence intensity (green channel) was detected from the bacteria treated with HLSn1. Typically, very few bacteria were stained by PI (red channel) after incubation with HLSn1 at low concentration (1 μg mL–1), which was in marked contrast to a large proportion of the bacteria stained by PI after treatment with HLSn1 at high concentration (50 μg mL–1). Meanwhile, superresolution micrographs of E. coli (e) under stimulated emission depletion (STED) nanoscopy demonstrated that complex HLSn1 was tightly adsorbed around the cell walls and even entered into the cells. Such results demonstrated that HLSn1 could act as a two-photon fluorescence probe for detecting bacteria and then killing them efficiently. In addition, we can preliminarily conclude that the bacterial death might be related to the destruction of the bacterial membranes.
elements.clean_text:
Study of the Antibacterial Mechanism

Given the remarkable two-photon absorption property of HLSn1, it was applied to obtain insight into the antibacterial process through two-photon confocal microscopy. Herein, propidium iodide (PI) without membrane permeability was chosen to color dead bacteria for comparison. As revealed in , intense fluorescence intensity (green channel) was detected from the bacteria treated with HLSn1. Typically, very few bacteria were stained by PI (red channel) after incubation with HLSn1 at low concentration (1 μg mL-1), which was in marked contrast to a large proportion of the bacteria stained by PI after treatment with HLSn1 at high concentration (50 μg mL-1). Meanwhile, superresolution micrographs of E. coli (e) under stimulated emission depletion (STED) nanoscopy demonstrated that complex HLSn1 was tightly adsorbed around the cell walls and even entered into the cells. Such results demonstrated that HLSn1 could act as a two-photon fluorescence probe for detecting bacteria and then killing them efficiently. In addition, we can preliminarily conclude that the bacterial death might be related to the destruction of the bacterial membranes.

elements.content: Two-photon fluorescence imaging of bacteria exposed to HLSn1 (1 μg mL–1 for parts a and c and 50 μg mL–1 for parts b and d) and cocultured with 1 μg mL–1 PI. Scale bar: 20 μm. Excited wavelength (PI, one-photon): 488 nm. Emission filter: 590–640 nm. Excited wavelength (HLSn1, two-photon): 840 nm. Emission filter: 520–580 nm. (e) Superresolution micrographs of E. coli cultivated with 50 μg mL–1 HLSn1. Scale bar: 1 μm. Excited wavelength (one-photon): 405 nm. Emission filter: 520–580 nm.

elements.content: According to the bacteria imaging results and previous studies, we hypothesized that the antibacterial mechanism of complex HLSn1 was attributed to the damage of the bacterial membrane. Lu et al. proposed that the surface of silver nanoparticles highly enriches the local charge density, which can result in a strong electrostatic interaction with the bacterial membrane and then efficient killing of the bacteria. Because the electron orbital of organotin­(IV) is the same as that of silver­(I), we expected the similar reason for HLSn1 damaging the bacterial membrane. Additionally, the flexible alkyl chains within the molecule HLSn1 may improve its lipophilicity and biocompatibility, making it readily absorbed by the bacterial membrane, resulting in damage to the bacterial membrane. To certify this idea, a UV-absorbance investigation at 260 nm was performed to detect the bacterial membrane integrity. a manifested an increasing absorption at 260 nm versus cultivation time ranging from 0 to 6 h, indicating that the bacterial membrane was destroyed by the complex HLSn1 and the cytoplasmic components were subsequently discharged from the bacteria cell.

elements.content: SEM was also used to further evaluate the change of the morphology and membrane integrity of bacterial cells before and after culturing with complex HLSn1. As shown in b, no obvious membrane damage or cell death could be observed in the absence of HLSn1. In stark contrast, most bacterial cells suffered from membrane disruption and cytoplasm leakage after exposure to HLSn1, which was in well accordance with the result of the absorption study and powerfully supported our hypothesis.

elements.content: Haydel, Leong, and co-workers demonstrated that an exorbitant level of ROS can enhance the oxidative stress in cells, which could destroy the bacterial membrane and induce cell death. Recently, 2′,7′-dichlorodihydrofluorescein diacetate (H2-DCFDA) was used as a standard fluorescence probe to detect the production of ROS in B. subtilis and E. coli cultured with complex HLSn1. As manifested in , remarkable fluorescence was found in B. subtilis and E. coli in the presence of complex HLSn1 and no fluorescence in the absence of complex HLSn1. Similar phenomena can be seen from the corresponding bacteria suspension under UV-light illumination (365 nm), indicating that the generation of ROS and subsequent membrane destruction might be the primary mechanism of the antimicrobial function. The results were also in accordance with the hypothesis for the antibacterial mechanism.

The control groups were prepared similarly without complex HLSn1. The photographs of the corresponding bacteria suspension were obtained under UV-light illumination (365 nm).

elements.content: In summary, a novel cyano coumarin-based ligand and its organotin­(IV) complexes (HLSn1 and HLSn2) were designed. The relationship between the structure and photophysical properties was evaluated both experimentally and theoretically. HLSn1 with remarkable two-photon activity was demonstrated to have the highest antibacterial activity among the complexes and ligand evaluated. It showed a lower MIC value (2 ± 0.14 μg mL–1) than Kana (8 ± 0.42 μg mL–1) against Gram-positiveB. subtilis. Importantly, the strong antibacterial activity of complex HLSn1 was confirmed to be the generation of ROS by superresolution development. Given that the complex HLSn1 possesses suitable biocompatibility and excellent penetration and can be facilely prepared at low cost, such organotin­(IV) materials may be expected to act as a powerful and practical tool for further application in the diagnostic and treatment of infectious disease.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a novel cyano coumarin-based ligand and its organotin(IV) complexes (HLSn1 and HLSn2) were designed. The relationship between the structure and photophysical properties was evaluated both experimentally and theoretically. HLSn1 with remarkable two-photon activity was demonstrated to have the highest antibacterial activity among the complexes and ligand evaluated. It showed a lower MIC value (2 ± 0.14 μg mL-1) than Kana (8 ± 0.42 μg mL-1) against Gram-positiveB. subtilis. Importantly, the strong antibacterial activity of complex HLSn1 was confirmed to be the generation of ROS by superresolution development. Given that the complex HLSn1 possesses suitable biocompatibility and excellent penetration and can be facilely prepared at low cost, such organotin(IV) materials may be expected to act as a powerful and practical tool for further application in the diagnostic and treatment of infectious disease.

To an acetonitrile solution (50 mL) of 7-(diethylamino)-2-oxo-2H-chromene-3-carbaldehyde (5 mmol, 1.20 g) was added cyanoacetic acid (10 mmol, 0.85 g) and then 3 drops of piperidine. The reaction mixture were stirred for 5 h at 80 °C. When cooled to room temperature, the solvent was removed to afford a coarse product and recrystallized in acetonitrile to obtain atrovirens solids. Yield: 85%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 400 MHz): δ 1.16 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 6H), 3.54 (q, J = 7.1 Hz, 4H), 6.65 (d, J = 1.9 Hz, 1H), 6.85 (dd, J 1= 9.2 Hz, J 2 = 6.4 Hz, 1H), 7.62 (d, J = 9.1 Hz, 1H), 8.25 (s, 1H), 8.76 (s, 1H), 13.67 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6, 100 MHz): δ 12.87, 45.12, 97.08, 99.60, 108.48, 109.99, 111.23, 117.11, 132.76, 144.33, 147.46, 153.88, 157.98, 160.67, 164.11. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3427, 2976, 2930, 2503, 2219, 1726, 1679, 1616, 1537, 1502, 1419, 1345, 1269, 1199, 1132, 1047, 1008, 963, 850, 812, 745, 638, 573, 528, 458. MS (MALDI-TOF, H). Calcd: m/z 312.11. Found: m/z 311.54. Anal. Calcd for C17H16N2O: C, 65.39; H, 5.17; N, 8.96. Found: C, 65.43; H, 5.14; N, 8.98.

Synthesis of <bold>HLSn1</bold>

A mixture of HL (2 mmol, 0.62 g) and bis­(tri-n-butyltin) oxide (1 mmol, 0.60 g) was dissolved in benzene (55 mL) under a N2 atmosphere. A clear solution was generated and refluxed for 12 h. Then, the solvent was removed to obtain compound HLSn1 (red solid; ). Yield: 92%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 400 MHz): δ 0.87 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 10H), 1.15 (m, 12H), 1.32 (m, 6H), 1.63 (m, 5H), 3.51 (q, J = 7.1 Hz, 4H), 6.61 (s, 1H), 6.80 (dd, J 1 = 6.8 Hz, J 2 = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.56 (d, J = 9.1 Hz, 1H), 8.11 (s, 1H), 8.66 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6, 100 MHz): δ 11.95, 14.01, 19.03, 26.37, 26.98, 43.85, 95.95, 107.71, 110.22, 117.68, 131.55, 142.72, 144.02, 152.60, 156.99, 160.31, 164.40. IR (KBr, cm–1): 2954, 2922, 2869, 2221, 1728, 1625, 1587, 1564, 1514, 1421, 1374, 1342, 1325, 1297, 1253, 1206, 1191, 1136, 1079, 1014, 966, 876, 796, 764, 750, 675, 640, 613, 573, 507, 469. 119Sn NMR (DMSO-d 6): δ −25.38. MS (MALDI-TOF, butyl). Calcd: m/z 602.22. Found: m/z 545.18. Anal. Calcd for C29H42N2O4Sn: C, 57.92; H, 7.03; N, 4.66. Found: C, 57.87; H, 7.07; N, 4.63.

Synthesis of <bold>HLSn2</bold> ()

Compound HLSn2 was produced by a method similar to that used for compound HLSn1, material HL (1 mmol, 0.31 g), and Ph3SnOH (1 equiv). Yield: 91%. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 400 MHz): δ 1.12 (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 6H), 3.47 (q, J = 6.7 Hz, 4H), 6.57 (s, 1H), 6.77 (dd, J 1 = 9.3 Hz, J 2 = 1.5 Hz, 1H), 7.49 (m, 10H), 7.87 (d, J = 6.4 Hz, 6H), 8.06 (s, 1H), 8.61 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6, 100 MHz): δ 11.93, 45.06, 96.48, 107.72, 110.26, 128.33, 129.01, 129.03, 131.60, 136.14, 136.37, 157.02, 160.24. IR (KBr, cm–1): 2968, 2228, 1717, 1641, 1619, 1565, 1509, 1479, 1454, 1374, 1430, 1287, 1254, 1207, 1136, 1194, 1093, 1079, 1011, 962, 902, 830, 798, 763, 782, 732, 698, 640, 616, 524, 470, 451. 119Sn NMR (DMSO): δ −263.51. MS (MALDI-TOF). Calcd: m/z 662.12. Found: m/z 662.36. Anal. Calcd for C35H30N2O4Sn: C, 63.56; H, 4.57; N, 4.24. Found: C, 63.61; H, 4.54; N, 4.28.

cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Synthetic Routes for HL, HLSn1, and HLSn2

cln_elements.content: Molecular structures of HLSn1 (a) and HLSn2 (c). All H atoms are omitted for clarity. The 1D linear chain of complexes HLSn1 (b) and HLSn2 (d). Single-crystal structures were present with 50% probability displacement ellipsoids.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular structures of HLSn1 (a) and HLSn2 (c). All H atoms are omitted for clarity. The 1D linear chain of complexes HLSn1 (b) and HLSn2 (d). Single-crystal structures were present with 50% probability displacement ellipsoids.

cln_elements.content: (a) Absorbance and emission spectra, (b) molecular orbital energy diagrams, and (c) two-photon-active cross sections of compounds HL, HLSn1, and HLSn2 in PBS (0.02% Triton X-100).
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Absorbance and emission spectra, (b) molecular orbital energy diagrams, and (c) two-photon-active cross sections of compounds HL, HLSn1, and HLSn2 in PBS (0.02% Triton X-100).

cln_elements.content: Normalized OD of E. coli and B. subtilis. Suspensions were measured at 600 nm in lysogeny broth at 37 °C after the introduction of different concentrations of HL, HLSn1, HLSn2, and Kana (DMSO solution), respectively, for 24 h. Control groups were bacteria-treated without antibacterial agents. The error bars represent the standard deviation (n = 3).
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Normalized OD of E. coli and B. subtilis. Suspensions were measured at 600 nm in lysogeny broth at 37 °C after the introduction of different concentrations of HL, HLSn1, HLSn2, and Kana (DMSO solution), respectively, for 24 h. Control groups were bacteria-treated without antibacterial agents. The error bars represent the standard deviation (n = 3).

cln_elements.content: (a) Inhibition zones of HLSn1 against E. coli and B. subtilis. (b) Bacterial growth curves of E. coli and (c) B. subtilis exposed to HLSn1 in LB media collected by the OD at 600 nm. Control groups were bacteria untreated with the antimicrobial material.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Inhibition zones of HLSn1 against E. coli and B. subtilis. (b) Bacterial growth curves of E. coli and (c) B. subtilis exposed to HLSn1 in LB media collected by the OD at 600 nm. Control groups were bacteria untreated with the antimicrobial material.

cln_elements.content: (a) 1H NMR spectral study of the stability of complex HLSn1 at D2O/DMSO-d 6 (1/5, v/v) at 25 or 37 °C for 24 h, respectively. (b) Cytoactivity of HELF cells exposed to HLSn1 for 24 h. (c) Two-photon fluorescent imaging of the 3D MCSs of a HepG2 cell treated with 1 μg mL–1 HLSn1 for 5 h. Excited wavelength (HLSn1, two-photon): 840 nm. Emission filter: 520–580 nm. Scale bar: 20 μm.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  (a) 1H NMR spectral study of the stability of complex HLSn1 at D2O/DMSO-d 6 (1/5, v/v) at 25 or 37 °C for 24 h, respectively. Excited wavelength (HLSn1, two-photon): 840 nm. Emission filter: 520-580 nm. Scale bar: 20 μm.

cln_elements.content: Two-photon fluorescence imaging of bacteria exposed to HLSn1 (1 μg mL–1 for parts a and c and 50 μg mL–1 for parts b and d) and cocultured with 1 μg mL–1 PI. Scale bar: 20 μm. Excited wavelength (PI, one-photon): 488 nm. Emission filter: 590–640 nm. Excited wavelength (HLSn1, two-photon): 840 nm. Emission filter: 520–580 nm. (e) Superresolution micrographs of E. coli cultivated with 50 μg mL–1 HLSn1. Scale bar: 1 μm. Excited wavelength (one-photon): 405 nm. Emission filter: 520–580 nm.
